Abstract This study proposes a novel approach
leveraging Large Language Models (LLMs) to gen-
erate dynamic and complex adaptable cybersecu-
rity exercise scenarios. Motivated by Turing’s sem-
inal exploration into machine cognition, which ques-
tions the ability of machines to mimic human thought
and intelligence. By exploiting the generative po-
tential of LLMs, our methodology simulates a wide
range of cyber threats, both known and novel, thereby
enhancing cybersecurity training and awareness.
This approach transforms the potential for ’hal-
lucination’ inherent in LLMs into a potential ad-
vantage, enabling the creation of complex exer-
cise scenarios that push the boundaries of tradi-
tional cybersecurity training. The innovation lies
in the sophisticated application of AI, aiming to
advance the preparedness of security professionals
against diverse cyber threats. The scenarios gener-
ated through this method were subject to meticu-
lous testing and a rigorous evaluation process in-
volving GPT models and expert review to ensure
their realism and applicability. Furthermore, the
prompts provided to the LLMs were meticulously
designed to adopt a Retrieval-Augmented Gener-
ation (RAG) approach, enriching the complexity
and relevance of the scenarios. This incorporation
of RAG, alongside the inspiration drawn from Tur-
ing’s exploration of machine intelligence, showcases
an advanced application of AI in cybersecurity train-
ing, reﬂecting a deep understanding of how ma-
chines can augment our capabilities to anticipate
and mitigate cyber threats.

1 Introduction
In the ever-evolving cyber domain, security profes-
sionals are continually seeking innovative strate-
gies to prepare for and reduce the impact of com-
plex threats. Cyber threats can take various forms,
including malware, phishing, ransomware, DDoS
attacks, social engineering, zero-day exploits, in-
sider threats, and advanced persistent threats [1,
2]. Adapting to these many threat types is criti-
cal for protecting organizations and digital assets
in an increasingly linked world [3]. Developing cy-
ber threat exercise scenarios is essential for the
planning process as it functions as both a train-
ing ground for security professionals and a test-
ing ground for system defenses. Constructing these
scenarios, which require both authenticity and com-
plexity, is a process that necessitates a detailed un-
derstanding of the threat environment as well as
the capacity to predict the activities of possible
adversaries. With organizations generating signif-
icant volumes of data daily, there’s an increasing
risk that this data that could be used for malicious
activities, eﬀectively turning seemingly harmless
information into a weapon for potentially breach-
ing security. Given this context, there is an ur-
gent requirement to address novel approaches that
can convert this data into valuable training sce-
narios, thereby transforming potential weaknesses
into strong defenses [4]. Within this context, Large
Language Models (LLMs) emerge as transforma-
tive tools, oﬀering the ability to generate detailed
and intricate content that can simulate potential
cyber threat scenarios. Given their generative abil-
ities, LLMs can go beyond simulating known cyber
threat scenarios and have the potential to gener-
ate diﬀerent types of novel and sophisticated cyber
2
threats, thus expanding the scope of cybersecurity
awareness and training.
In this paper, we propose an innovative use of
LLM hallucination to create a sophisticated and
adaptive cyber threat scenario. Our approach trans-
forms this hallucination into a useful tool for gen-
erating diverse cyber threat exercise scenarios. We
establish a pipeline involving multiple LLMs that
interactively communicate, setting up a dynamic
environment for cyber-attack scenarios. In this setup,
one LLM adopts the role of a ’Cyber Security Ex-
pert’, while the other acts as a ’CISO of an Orga-
nization’. Uniquely, the ’CISO’ is aware of docu-
ments containing various organizational functions
like ﬁnance, HR, and IT infrastructure while the
’Cyber Security Expert’ is aware of the current
cyber threat landscape. The documents serve as
a prompt for the ’CISO’ to utilize its hallucina-
tion capability in generating diﬀerent types of cy-
ber threats. This method not only capitalizes on
the often-overlooked hallucinatory aspect of LLMs
but also elevates it as a pivotal feature in craft-
ing realistic, adaptable, and comprehensive cyber
threat scenarios. This novel application of LLM
hallucination in cybersecurity represents a signif-
icant advancement, transforming a perceived lim-
itation into a vital asset for strengthening digital
security infrastructures. Just like in Alan Turing’s
”Imitation Game” where we have three characters
an integrator and two individuals discussing a sub-
ject to identify who is a machine and who is a
human. In our case we have predeﬁned prompts
acting as interrogators while two LLMs discussing
the threat landscape for creating a cyber security
scenario. We identiﬁed that our approach is suit-
able for generating new and unique cybersecurity
exercise scenarios and can have other potential use
cases. The structure of the remainder of this paper
is organized as follows: Section (2) reviews the cy-
ber security scenarios. Section (3) details the sce-
nario design process. Section (4) is dedicated to
the proposed system design. Section (5) is based
on the case study. In the concluding phase, Sec-
tion (6) concludes the paper and outlines future
work.
2 Background and Related Work
2.1 Cyber security scenarios
There are two primary types of cybersecurity exer-
cises: tabletop discussions and hands-on operation-
based exercises [5–7]. Tabletop exercises involve
discussions and are often conducted through sem-
inars, workshops, and idea exchanges, primarily
focusing on policy-related issues. In comparison,
operation-based cybersecurity training programs
emphasize practical, hands-on activities aimed at
enhancing participants’ technical skills and abili-
ties. These exercises take place in simulated, em-
ulated, physical, or hybrid practice environments.
Recent studies have found that the creation of these
practice environments, known as cyber-ranges, of-
ten relies on manual setup and conﬁguration. This
approach is not only ineﬀective but also prone to
errors, making it a tedious process [8]. A similar
approach was introduced by C. Chindrus et al. [9],
their research study proposed a practical approach
to enhancing cybersecurity readiness through a sim-
ulated ’Red’ and ’Blue’ cybersecurity competition.
The study assesses its impact on incident response
capabilities and cybersecurity skills development,
emphasizing the value of immersive training expe-
riences and knowledge exchange for proactive cy-
bersecurity mindsets and cyber resilience [10].
In their study, M. Yamin et al. [11] developed
a serious game designed to enhance the develop-
ment of cyber-security exercise scenarios, address-
ing the ineﬃciencies in traditional exercise prepa-
rations. Their study made use of a Domain Spe-
ciﬁc Language (DSL) and infrastructure coordina-
tion which allows users to mimic real-time cyber-
security scenarios as attackers or defenders. This
approach not only streamlines the scenario cre-
ation process but also allows for extensive test-
ing in a simulated environment before deployment
in realistic settings. Their proposed method repre-
sents a signiﬁcant advancement in cyber-security
training, focusing on operational strategy devel-
opment and eﬀective scenario modeling.
R. Nakata et al. [12] introduced a Docker-based
cyber range system, designed to address the grow-
ing need for eﬀective information security educa-
tion by automatically generating multiple random-
ized scenarios using Directed Acyclic Graph (DAG)
techniques [13–15]. With the increasing reliance on
information technology, the importance of cyber
range exercises in security training is highlighted.
Traditional methods often suﬀer from the overuse
of limited scenarios, which can reduce educational
impact due to predictability and information leak-
age. CyExec* overcomes these challenges by pro-
viding diverse, randomized scenarios that maintain
the same learning objectives, enhancing teaching
eﬀectiveness and mitigating the risk of cheating.
Compared to VM-based systems, CyExec* demon-
strates signiﬁcant improvements in resource eﬃ-
ciency, using less memory, CPU, and storage, thus
enabling more complex scenarios to be run simul-
3
taneously. This paper has described the architec-
ture and eﬀectiveness of CyExec*, comparing it to
existing platforms, and discusses future enhance-
ments aimed at enriching scenario variety, online
exercise application, and evaluating educational im-
pact.
M. Yamin et al. [16] introduced an innovative
system designed to address the ineﬃciencies in con-
ducting cyber-security exercises within cyber ranges
after conducting a detailed study on unclassiﬁed
cyber-ranges [17]. It acknowledges the complexity
and resource-intensive nature of current practices,
which often fail to replicate the dynamic nature
of real-world systems. To counter this, the authors
introduced an automated approach using model-
driven methods to streamline the cyber-security
exercise life cycle. Their system models the roles
of various teams such as White, Green, Red, and
Blue, and generates automation artifacts to exe-
cute these functions autonomously, adding real-
ism to the exercises. The system was evaluated
through case studies involving national-level com-
petitions and university classes in Norway, demon-
strating its ability to rapidly create complex in-
frastructures and improve participant skills. The
paper addressed four key research questions focus-
ing on eﬃciency, adaptability, autonomy, and skill
enhancement in cyber-security exercises.
M. Yamin et al. [18] presented an advanced
agent-based system for realistic and eﬃcient cyber-
security training, utilizing a newly developed for-
mal model called the Execution Plan (EP) to au-
tomate cyber attack and defense scenarios in cyber
exercises. This approach addresses the challenges
of involving human teams in large-scale cybersecu-
rity exercises, which often lead to ineﬃciencies and
inconsistencies. The system is evaluated through a
case study, demonstrating its eﬀectiveness in pro-
viding realistic training environments. It also em-
phasizes the use of domain-speciﬁc language for
scenario modeling and the integration of various
cyber exercise components, aiming to automate
the entire cybersecurity exercise life cycle. In their
study, F. Lemjan et al. [19] investigated the secu-
rity vulnerabilities of Internet of Things (IoT) de-
vices, emphasizing the need for autonomous pene-
tration testing to address these risks. The research
explores automated attack execution models for
simulating attacks in cyber ranges and applies these
models to autonomously test IoT device security.
A case study shows the eﬀectiveness of these mod-
els in identifying known Wi-Fi vulnerabilities in
current IoT products. The study also highlights
the limitations and potential improvements in pen-
etration testing methodologies, such as network in-
terface range and password cracking techniques,
underscoring the evolving nature of cybersecurity
threats and the need for continuously updated au-
tomated testing tools. The research advocates for
stronger security measures, like the adoption of
WPA3 and robust password policies, to mitigate
the vulnerabilities found in widely used IoT de-
vices.
A. Zacharis et al. [20] described a novel method
for automating the creation of structured cyber-
security exercise scenarios. Their proposed work
included Machine Learning (ML), more especially
Name Entity Recognition (NER), to evaluate un-
structured data and provide meaningful, structured
scenarios for cybersecurity training. The document
describes the creation and implementation of a
unique ontology, the cyber exercise scenario on-
tology, which aims to structure created content in
a way that is both machine and human-readable.
Their research methodology intends to increase the
speed, quality, and relevance of cybersecurity exer-
cise scenarios scenario development, primarily aid-
ing exercise planners with little experience in sce-
nario building. These exercises are crucial in en-
abling IT professionals and cybersecurity teams
to eﬀectively prevent and mitigate cyber threats.
The methodology being explored intends to im-
prove these training modules by proposing a novel
technique for creating cyber exercise content. This
strategy uses AI and machine learning technology
to create situations that are detailed, technically
sound, realistic, and imaginative. However, this re-
search study’s proposed framework AI-Assisted Cy-
ber Exercise Content Generation Framework using
Named Entity Recognition (AiCEF) has certain
limitations, such as the need to expand the range
of data sources, including threat intelligence re-
ports and alerts, to enhance scenario generation
within AiCEF. Moreover, reﬁning the text synthe-
sis mechanism to exclusively utilize cybersecurity-
speciﬁc resources would improve the accuracy of
technical terminologies. Additionally, the threat
actor description component of AiCEF requires
targeted enhancements to more eﬀectively address
the intricate dynamics of cybersecurity threats. By
using basic AI, the method may not fully capture
the nuanced dynamics of cyber threats and oper-
ational challenges, emphasizing the need for more
advanced solutions like LLMs to enhance scenario
development with greater creativity and intricacy.
4
2.2 LLMs
In the ﬁeld of Machine Learning (ML), the prac-
tice of initially training models on general tasks
and then ﬁne-tuning them for speciﬁc applications
has been a well-established technique in 2010, par-
ticularly in computer vision. However, signiﬁcant
adoption of this method began in the latter half
of the decade, with the development of the Trans-
former architecture [21,22]. The advent of the Trans-
former model revolutionized the ﬁeld of Natural
Language Processing (NLP) by addressing some
of the key limitations of previous architectures,
such as Recurrent Neural Networks (RNNs). Un-
like RNNs that process data sequentially, Trans-
formers parallelize the computations, which signif-
icantly speeds up training. RNNs heavily relied on
predicting the next word based on the previous
one, often leading to inaccurate predictions. The
self-attention mechanism of a Transformer allows
each position in the encoder to attend to all po-
sitions in the previous layer of the encoder, simi-
larly for the decoder enabling the model to capture
long-range dependencies with ease [23, 24]. Build-
ing upon the Transformer architecture, pre-trained
models such as Bidirectional Encoder Represen-
tations from Transformers (BERT) and Genera-
tive Pretrained Transformers (GPT) represent the
class of LLMs. These LLMs are trained on massive
amounts of data, learning a rich representation of
language that captures a wide spectrum of linguis-
tic patterns, idioms, and structures. They excel
over prior models by being adept at a wide range
of tasks without task-speciﬁc architecture modiﬁ-
cations, largely due to their extensive pretraining,
which imparts a broad understanding of language.
This pretraining aspect allows them to be ﬁne-
tuned for speciﬁc tasks with relatively little addi-
tional data, making them highly versatile and pow-
erful tools for NLP applications. LLMs are used in
chatbots, virtual assistants, and customer service
automation to understand and generate human-
like responses [25] [26]. These advanced language
models also assist in writing articles, generating
creative content, and summarizing texts [27] [28].

LLMs represent a signiﬁcant leap in Artiﬁcial
Intelligence (AI) capabilities, having been trained
on trillions of words over extensive periods using
considerable computational resources. The expan-
sive parameter sets in these models endow them
with extensive ’memory’, allowing them to tackle
increasingly complex tasks. While LLMs are pow-
erful out-of-the-box tools, their full potential can
be utilized through ﬁne-tuning, which adapts them
to particular tasks beyond their initial training
scope. LLMs excel at interpreting natural language
instructions and executing tasks with a proﬁciency
comparable to human performance [29–32]. The
input text provided to an LLM serves as a ’ prompt’
within what is known as the ’ context window’
the active ﬁeld where the model processes infor-
mation. Utilizing LLMs to generate text, a pro-
cess termed ’inference,’ relies on the foundational
technique of next-word prediction, which supports
many of their diverse text-generating tasks [33–36].
In the context of LLMs, the term ’ completion’
signiﬁes the output generated, which may encom-
pass more than just single-word predictions and
often constitutes full sentences or even paragraphs
in response to given prompts.
Through ﬁne-tuning and the prompt engineer-
ing, LLMs can be informed about speciﬁc tasks
that are not covered during pretraining, thus em-
powering them to interact eﬀectively with real-
world scenarios. It is within the multitude of pa-
rameters that LLMs encapsulate their understand-
ing of language, enabling them to analyze, deduce,
and resolve the challenges presented to them. In
addition to their impressive capabilities, it’s im-
portant to acknowledge that LLMs are not with-
out their limitations. One notable concern is the
potential for hallucination, where they generate in-
formation that is not grounded in reality or might
propagate false or misleading content. We utilised
this feature of LLMs in our study to provide them
context of cybersecuirty scenarios through prompt
engineering.

2.3 Hallucination in LLMs
Hallucination in LLMs is an issue that arises due
to the vast amount of data they have been trained
on, which may include inaccuracies or biased in-
formation, this issue emerges as a result of the
model’s capacity to generate text that adheres to
learned patterns from its training data, even when
the generated content diverges from reality [37]
and this phenomenon could pose serious risks in
diverse ﬁelds, including law and medical consul-
tation, potentially leading to disasters. Address-
ing and mitigating the risk of hallucination is an
ongoing challenge in the development and deploy-
ment of LLMs, requiring careful monitoring, ethi-
cal guidelines, and continuous reﬁnement of their
algorithms and training data. One of the various
reasons for hallucination in LLMs, as identiﬁed by
[38], is that nonsensical Out-of-Distribution (OoD)
prompts, composed of random tokens, can also elicit
hallucinatory responses from these language mod-
els. Some methods to minimize hallucination in-
clude SELFCHECKGPT [39], robust instruction
tuning [40], knowledge injection [41], self-reﬂection
mechanisms [42], and contrastive learning [43]. While
hallucination in LLMs is often regarded as a limita-
tion and potential source of misinformation, there
are several situations in which it could be advan-
tageous if used correctly. Controlled hallucination
can serve as a valuable tool in various creative and
exploratory contexts. For instance, LLMs can be
used to generate imaginative and creative content,
such as ﬁction, poetry, or art descriptions, push-
ing the boundaries of traditional human creativ-
ity [44–46]. This kind of creativity is required for
generating new and unique cybersecuirty exercises
scenarios and LLMs hallucination can play an im-
portant role in it.
3 Scenario Design Process
Taking inspiration from eLuna [47] game design
process we theorized to use the same approach to
create scenarios for cybersecurity exercises. The
eLuna framework exempliﬁes a methodical brain-
storming process tailored for the collaborative de-
sign of narrative Digital Game-Based Learning (DGBL)
experiences. It facilitates a creative dialogue be-
tween educators and game developers, employing
a visual language to articulate and merge edu-
cational objectives with engaging gameplay ele-
ments. In the initial co-design phase, this brain-
storming approach allows for the ﬂexible integra-
tion of diverse ideas, nurturing an innovative envi-
ronment that captures the educational intent within
the game’s narrative. As the process transitions
to the co-speciﬁcation phase, the brainstorming
becomes more structured, converging towards a
detailed and technical blueprint that guides the
game’s development. LLMs can signiﬁcantly en-
hance this brainstorming activity by generating
rich, context-aware content that aligns with the
established educational themes, thereby enriching
the narrative depth and bolstering the learning ex-
perience [ ?]. By leveraging the generative capabil-
ities of LLMs, the eLuna Framework can produce
DGBL solutions that are not only captivating and
educational but also infused with the creative in-
sights obtained from a comprehensive brainstorm-
ing process. Furthermore, in the ﬁelds of art and
music composition, controlled hallucination can re-
sult in the creation of one-of-a-kind and innova-
tive works oﬀering a fresh perspective that might
resonate with certain audiences. In cybersecurity
exercises, we have a scenario design process with
various phases: preparation, dry run, execution,
evaluation, and repetition. In this work we focused
on the preparation phase of cybersecuirty exercises
scenarios and use similar conpets to eluna to de-
scribe requirements for cyberscuirty exercises sce-
narios.
3.1 Preparation
In the ”preparation” phase of the scenario design
process, we have six crucial modules including story,
entity, infrastructure, conditions, events, and TLO’s.
Figure 1 represents the all steps in the preparation
phase which has been discussed in detail below.
1. Story: The story of a cybersecurity exercise
sets the ﬁctional backdrop and events for the
scenario. In cybersecurity exercises, the main
story sets the overall context, such as a cyber-
attack on a ﬁnancial institution. Sub-stories,
which detail related incidents like internal net-
work breaches or customer data theft, support
and elaborate on the main story, adding depth
and complexity to the scenario. These sub-stories
(scripts), may also include incidents like at-
tacks on third-party vendors. The story can be
broken down into diﬀerent scripts, each con-
taining a series of events that form a narrative.
Each script presents a part of the story from
the viewpoint of one or more entities. A story
also has an internal speed that governs the ex-

4 System Design
Our system design is based on generating cyber ex-
ercise scenarios using two LLMs in parallel. LLM1
acts as the Chief Information Security Oﬃcer (CISO)
of the organization and possesses knowledge about
the organization, while the second LLM is a se-
curity expert well-informed about the current cy-
ber environment 3. Both LLMs operate within the
bounds of their rationality and pre-trained knowl-
edge. Furthermore, these LLMs have been conﬁg-
ured with a RAG technique to generate more re-
alistic scenarios.

4.1 Bounded Rationality
Herbert A. Simon introduced the concept of bounded
rationality, which questions the idea of humans
making purely rational decisions 4. This theory posits
that individuals operate within three inherent lim-
itations:
1. Limited Information: Individuals do not have
access to all information in their environment.
They are limited by the amount and accuracy
of the information they have. Apart from envi-
ronmental limitations, individuals’ backgrounds,
experiences, and perceptual biases play signiﬁ-
cant roles in determining the information they
seek out and rely on. This selective exposure
can result in what is referred to as ’bounded ra-
tionality,’ wherein decision-making occurs within
the conﬁnes of an individual’s understanding
and cognitive capacity.
2. Limited Cognitive Capacity: Individuals have
a limited capacity for processing information
and cannot realistically grasp all possible al-
ternatives or consequences when making deci-
sions. Cognitive constraints may prompt the
adoption of heuristic mental shortcuts, which
can be eﬃcient but also prone to errors. The
impact of cognitive load is signiﬁcant in com-
plex tasks where the individual must hold mul-
tiple pieces of information in working memory
while attempting to discern relevant patterns
or implications.
3. Limited Time: Individuals must make deci-
sions within certain time constraints, meaning
they cannot always analyze every option thor-
oughly. The advantage of having more time per-
mits a more comprehensive collection of infor-
mation and analysis, leading to more deliberate
decisions. Nevertheless, in high-speed scenar-
ios, the necessity to respond swiftly can often
outweigh the need for detailed analysis, result-
ing in decisions that are practical rather than
thorough.

Framework
Our developed framework, as depicted in Figure

threat scenarios. LLM1 crafts this initial narrative,

cyber security frameworks to formulate a detailed
and actionable cyber exercise narrative. This iter-
ative process results in a clear, actionable story,
outlining speciﬁc threats and a sequence of inci-
dents for the exercise.
In the second iteration, LLM1 expands the sce-
nario by integrating characters and agents reﬂect-
ing the organization’s roles and responsibilities.
LLM2 assigns speciﬁc tasks to these entities within
the exercise context, ensuring actions align with
the organization’s policies and the broader train-
ing objectives. As the narrative progresses, LLM1
details the organization’s infrastructure, laying out
the technological framework and security mea-
sures. LLM2 then crafts the virtual environment
for the exercise, mirroring the actual infrastruc-
ture to provide a realistic setting for scenario en-
actment.
In the fourth iteration, the ’Events and In-
jects Prompt’ prompts LLM1 to introduce var-
ious planned events and spontaneous ’injects’,
emulating the unpredictability of real cyber in-
cidents. LLM2 incorporates these elements, cre-
ating dynamic challenges that test participants’
decision-making and adaptability. Finally, the
’TLOs Prompt’ has LLM1 deﬁne the Training
and Learning Objectives (TLOs), identifying de-
sired skills and knowledge outcomes. LLM2 en-
sures the exercise’s design and content align with
these TLOs, facilitating measurable improvement
in cybersecurity capabilities.
4.5 Evaluation Methodology
To objectively assess the eﬀectiveness and educa-
tional value of the cyber exercise scenarios gen-
erated by LLM1 and LLM2, we employ a multi-
dimensional evaluation framework. This frame-
work consists of six key criteria: Details, Technical
Soundness, Realism, Creativity, Usability in Exer-
cises, and Expandability with Human Inputs. Each
criterion is assigned a value between 0 to 5, where 0
represents the minimum and 5 the maximum score,
to quantify the scenarios’ attributes comprehen-
sively. These factors ensure that exercises are real-
istic, engaging, and technically accurate, reﬂecting
the complexity of real-world cyber threats. They
enrich the creativity, encouraging learners to think
critically and innovatively. Usability ensures exer-
11
cises are accessible and beneﬁcial for a wide range
of users, while expandability with human inputs
allows for continuous updates and relevance in a
rapidly evolving cybersecurity landscape. The six
crucial criteria have been utilized for evaluating
both scenarios, whereby we assessed them with the
guidance of security experts (Human Evaluators)
and also employed the GPT model for evaluation.
Subsequently, we validated our ﬁndings to ensure
a comprehensive assessment and robust results.
1. Details: Details are the precision and speci-
ﬁcity in the generated cyber exercise scenarios,
ensuring that they accurately reﬂect the com-
plexity of real-world cybersecurity threats and
incidents.
2. Technical Soundness: The extent to which
the generated cyber threat scenarios are built
on cybersecurity concepts and accurately rep-
resent the technological aspects of cyber
threats, vulnerabilities, and defenses.
3. Realism: Realism is the incorporation of ac-
curate, contemporary cyber threat environ-
ment and attack methodologies into the sce-
narios, ensuring they mirror the intricacies and
unpredictability of actual cybersecurity inci-
dents. This aspect demands the scenarios to
be grounded in current cyber threat intelli-
gence, including the latest vulnerabilities, at-
tack vectors, and threat actor tactics, tech-
niques, and procedures (TTPs). Realism en-
hances the training’s eﬀectiveness by providing
participants with experiences that closely sim-
ulate real-world challenges, preparing them to
respond more eﬀectively to actual cybersecu-
rity incidents.
4. Creativity: Creativity can be deﬁned as the
framework’s ability to generate novel and var-
ied scenarios that go beyond standard or pre-
viously known cybersecurity incidents, encour-
aging innovative thinking and responses.
5. Usability in Exercises: The practicality and
eﬀectiveness of the generated scenarios in cy-
bersecurity training exercises, including how
easily they can be integrated into training ses-
sions and understood by participants.
6. Expandability with Human Inputs: The
capability of the framework to incorporate
expert feedback and real-world developments
into the scenario generation process, allowing
for continuous improvement and adaptation to
emerging cyber threats.

vative and eﬀective for training. The methodology
